question: A 61-year-old male presents to his primary care doctor with a six-month history of progressively worsening cough, shortness of breath, and 15-pound weight loss. Over the same time period, he has also started to notice occasional weakness in his legs that has made it difficult for him to stand up from his chair and climb stairs. The weakness appears to improve when he exercises at his local aerobics class. His past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes per day for 35 years. Chest radiographs demonstrate a perihilar mass in his right lung. A biopsy of the lung lesion is shown. Which of the following is most likely true about this patient?
correct_answer: His weakness is due to a type III hypersensitivity reaction
options: A)His weakness is due to a type III hypersensitivity reaction
B)He is at high risk of developing extraocular weakness
C)His weakness improves when calcium builds up in the presynaptic nerve terminal
D)His weakness is due to antibodies directed against post-synaptic, voltage-gated ion channels
prompt:
Q:A 61-year-old male presents to his primary care doctor with a six-month history of progressively worsening cough, shortness of breath, and 15-pound weight loss. Over the same time period, he has also started to notice occasional weakness in his legs that has made it difficult for him to stand up from his chair and climb stairs. The weakness appears to improve when he exercises at his local aerobics class. His past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes per day for 35 years. Chest radiographs demonstrate a perihilar mass in his right lung. A biopsy of the lung lesion is shown. Which of the following is most likely true about this patient?A)His weakness is due to a type III hypersensitivity reaction B)He is at high risk of developing extraocular weakness C)His weakness improves when calcium builds up in the presynaptic nerve terminal D)His weakness is due to antibodies directed against post-synaptic, voltage-gated ion channels

A:
output2: <bot>: The patient's symptoms of progressive cough, shortness of breath, and 15-pound weight loss, as well as the perihilar mass in his right lung on chest radiographs, are consistent with a diagnosis of lung cancer. The patient's history of smoking 2 packs of cigarettes per day for 35 years increases his risk of developing lung cancer. The patient's weakness is likely due to a type III hypersensitivity reaction, which is a common complication of lung cancer. The risk of extraocular weakness is high in patients with lung cancer.
output4: <bot> A: The patient's symptoms of progressive weakness in the legs, which improves with exercise, are consistent with a type of peripheral neuropathy called chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP). CIDP is an autoimmune disorder that is characterized by the production of antibodies directed against post-synaptic, voltage-gated ion channels. The antibodies disrupt the function of these channels, leading to weakness and wasting of the muscles. The patient's history of smoking and the presence of a perihilar mass in his right lung are also consistent with the diagnosis of CIDP.

question: Which of the following is not hyperthermia (heat therapy) treatment effect?
prompt:
Q:Which of the following is not hyperthermia (heat therapy) treatment effect?A)Increased metabolic rate B)Vasodilation C)Reduced pain thresholds D)Muscle ligament laxity

A:
output1: <bot> A: Because hyperthermia treatment is designed to increase body temperature, which can lead to increased metabolic rate, but it does not directly affect pain thresholds, vasodilation, or muscle ligament laxity.
output2: <bot>: Vasodilation is not a treatment effect of hyperthermia. The other options are all potential effects of hyperthermia: increased metabolic rate, reduced pain thresholds, and muscle ligament laxity.
output3: <bot>: Because hyperthermia increases the temperature of the tissues, which can cause vasodilation, increased metabolic rate, and muscle ligament laxity, but it does not directly affect pain thresholds. Pain thresholds are determined by the central nervous system, and hyperthermia does not have a direct effect on the central nervous system.
output4: <bot>: Muscle ligament laxity is not a known effect of hyperthermia treatment. The other options are all known effects of hyperthermia: increased metabolic rate (which can help to increase the body's ability to heal), vasodilation (which can improve circulation and reduce blood pressure), and reduced pain thresholds (which can make it easier to perform physical therapy and other treatments).

question: A 65-year-old asian man presents to his primary care physician because of abdominal distension, right upper quadrant (RUQ) abdominal pain, decreased appetite, and weight loss for several weeks. He denies smoking or excess alcohol intake. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F), blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 85/min. Physical examination reveals a cachectic man with jaundice, palmar erythema, ascites, and a palpable mass in the RUQ. Abdominal ultrasound shows a 3 cm hypoechoic mass in the right lobe of the liver. Alpha fetoprotein (AFP) is 500 μg/L. Which of the following is a risk factor for this patient condition?
prompt:
Q:A 65-year-old asian man presents to his primary care physician because of abdominal distension, right upper quadrant (RUQ) abdominal pain, decreased appetite, and weight loss for several weeks. He denies smoking or excess alcohol intake. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F), blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 85/min. Physical examination reveals a cachectic man with jaundice, palmar erythema, ascites, and a palpable mass in the RUQ. Abdominal ultrasound shows a 3 cm hypoechoic mass in the right lobe of the liver. Alpha fetoprotein (AFP) is 500 μg/L. Which of the following is a risk factor for this patient condition?A)Chronic hepatitis C infection B)Cyclophosphamide use C)Clonorchis sinensis infection D)Exposure to nitrosamines

A:
output1: <bot>: Chronic hepatitis C infection is a known risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), which is the most common type of primary liver cancer. The risk of developing HCC is increased in patients with chronic hepatitis C infection, especially those with advanced fibrosis or cirrhosis. The patient's history of abdominal distension, right upper quadrant pain, decreased appetite, and weight loss, along with the physical examination findings of jaundice, palmar erythema, and ascites, are all consistent with advanced liver disease. The presence of a 3 cm hypoechoic mass in the right lobe of the liver on abdominal ultrasound is also highly suggestive of HCC. The elevated AFP level further supports this diagnosis. Therefore, chronic hepatitis C infection is the most likely risk factor for this patient's condition.
output2: <bot>: Cyclophosphamide use is a risk factor for the development of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in patients with chronic liver disease. The patient's history of exposure to cyclophosphamide increases the likelihood of HCC as the underlying cause of the mass in the liver.
output3: <bot>: Clonorchis sinensis is a parasitic infection that is endemic in certain parts of Asia and can cause liver damage and mass lesions. The patient's history of exposure to this parasite is a risk factor for the development of liver disease, including the mass lesion observed in the ultrasound.
output4: <bot>: Exposure to nitrosamines is a risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), which is the most common primary liver cancer. Nitrosamines are known to cause DNA damage and can lead to the development of cancer. The patient's history of exposure to nitrosamines increases the likelihood of HCC as the underlying cause of the mass in the right lobe of the liver.

question: To what bacterial genus does the species causing diphtheria belong?
prompt:
Q:To what bacterial genus does the species causing diphtheria belong?A)Acinetobacter B)Corynebacterium. C)Brucella. D)Mycoplasma

A:
output1: <bot>: The species causing diphtheria is Corynebacterium diphtheriae, which belongs to the genus Corynebacterium.
output2: <bot>: The species causing diphtheria is Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
output3: <bot>: The species causing diphtheria belongs to the genus Corynebacterium.
output4:
<bot>: Because Mycoplasma is a genus of bacteria that includes the species Mycoplasma diphtheriae, which causes diphtheria.
<human>

question: Naloxone is used in the treatment of poisoning with:
prompt:
Q:Naloxone is used in the treatment of poisoning with:A)Tricyclic antidepressants. B)Benzodiazepines. C)Opiates D)Digitálicos.

A:
output1: <bot>: Naloxone is an antagonist of the opioid receptor, which is not affected by tricyclic antidepressants. Therefore, naloxone is not used in the treatment of poisoning with tricyclic antidepressants.
output2: <bot>: Naloxone is an antidote to benzodiazepines, which can cause respiratory depression and overdose. It works by blocking the effects of benzodiazepines on the nervous system, reversing the sedative and hypnotic effects, and helping to restore normal breathing.
output3: <bot>: Naloxone is an antagonist of opioid receptors, so it is used to reverse the effects of opioid overdose or poisoning.
output4: <bot>: Naloxone is an antagonist of opioid receptors, so it is used to reverse the effects of opioid overdose or poisoning.

question: Regarding terminal sedation, point out the INCORRECT response:
correct_answer: It should be used even if it is suspected that it will be responsible for shortening the patient's life.
options: A)It is indicated in patients who are close to his death.
B)It should be used even if it is suspected that it will be responsible for shortening the patient's life.
C)It is not indicated when the terminal patient requests it, citing existential reasons.
D)It should be used to relieve symptoms refractory to conventional treatments.
prompt:
Q:Regarding terminal sedation, point out the INCORRECT response:A)It is indicated in patients who are close to his death. B)It should be used even if it is suspected that it will be responsible for shortening the patient's life. C)It is not indicated when the terminal patient requests it, citing existential reasons. D)It should be used to relieve symptoms refractory to conventional treatments.

A:
output1: <bot>: Because sedation can cause respiratory depression, which can hasten death.
output2: <bot>: Because it is not appropriate to intentionally hasten the patient's death, even if the patient is close to death. Terminal sedation should only be used to relieve symptoms refractory to conventional treatments, and not as a means of ending the patient's life.
output3:
<bot>: Because terminal sedation is not a treatment for existential reasons, but rather a medical intervention to alleviate symptoms.
<human>
output4: <bot>: Because the other options are not correct.

question: Which of the following is the most commonly used drug for management of community acquired pneumonia?
prompt:
Q:Which of the following is the most commonly used drug for management of community acquired pneumonia?A)Streptomycin B)Vancomycin C)Azithromycin D)Ceftriaxone

A:
output1: <bot>: Streptomycin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that is effective against a wide range of bacteria, including those that cause community-acquired pneumonia. It has been widely used for many years and has a good track record of effectiveness and safety.
output2: <bot>: Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic that is effective against a wide range of gram-positive bacteria, including Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia. Additionally, Vancomycin has a long half-life, which allows for once-daily dosing and can be administered orally or intravenously.

question: A patient with history of frequent abortions and pain in calf muscles from past 4 years is due to deficiency of
prompt:
Q:A patient with history of frequent abortions and pain in calf muscles from past 4 years is due to deficiency ofA)Plasmin B)Factory VII C)Thrombin D)Protein c

A:
output1: <bot>: Plasmin is a proteolytic enzyme that is involved in the breakdown of blood clots. Frequent abortions and pain in the calf muscles can be symptoms of a bleeding disorder, such as hemophilia A, which is caused by a deficiency of factor VIII. Factor VIII is a clotting factor that is necessary for the formation of a stable clot. Plasmin is involved in the dissolution of the clot, so if there is a deficiency of plasmin, the clot may not be properly dissolved, leading to bleeding and pain.
output2: <bot>: Factory VII is a protein that is involved in the formation of blood clots. The patient's history of frequent abortions and pain in calf muscles suggests that they may have a bleeding disorder, which could be caused by a deficiency of Factory VII.
output3: <bot>: Thrombin is a clotting factor that is involved in the formation of blood clots. Frequent abortions and calf muscle pain can be caused by a deficiency of thrombin, leading to an increased risk of blood clots forming in the body.
output4: <bot>: Protein C is a vitamin K-dependent protein that plays a role in the regulation of blood coagulation. It is also involved in the inhibition of thrombin, which is a clotting factor. In the case of the patient with a history of frequent abortions and pain in calf muscles, the deficiency of Protein C may be contributing to the development of thrombosis, which can cause abortion. Additionally, the patient's history of frequent abortions may be due to the deficiency of Protein C, which is essential for the proper regulation of blood coagulation.

question: Has the lowest feel normal threshold (the lowest stimulation threshold) Which of the following taste for?
prompt:
Q:Has the lowest feel normal threshold (the lowest stimulation threshold) Which of the following taste for?A)acid B)bitter C)sweet D)salty

A:
output1: <bot>: Because the lowest feel normal threshold is associated with the sensation of acidity.
output2: <bot>: Because the lowest feel normal threshold is associated with the perception of bitterness.
output3: <bot>: Because the lowest feel normal threshold is associated with the perception of sweetness. Sweetness is the taste that is most easily detected by the taste buds, and it has the lowest stimulation threshold. This means that the taste buds can detect sweetness at a lower concentration of sweet substances than they can detect other tastes, such as acidity or bitterness.
output4: <bot>: Because the taste buds for salty taste are more sensitive and have a lower threshold for detection than the taste buds for other tastes. This means that a smaller amount of salt is needed to detect the taste than for other tastes.

question: A 24-year-old student of mathematics, who comes to the clinic to confirm the diagnostic suspicion after a consultation in Google. Since childhood he has episodes of intense pain, lancinating, in hands and feet, lasting between minutes and days. He relates them to physical exercise, stress or fever, and was diagnosed with "growing pains". Later he notes that he does not have sweating after playing sports. He has also observed punctate skin lesions, of a dark red color, in "the swimsuit zone", considered non-specific. Get the diagnosis after collecting three keys (painful neuropathy, hypohidrosis and angiokeratomas). What do you think is the diagnosis?
prompt:
Q:A 24-year-old student of mathematics, who comes to the clinic to confirm the diagnostic suspicion after a consultation in Google. Since childhood he has episodes of intense pain, lancinating, in hands and feet, lasting between minutes and days. He relates them to physical exercise, stress or fever, and was diagnosed with "growing pains". Later he notes that he does not have sweating after playing sports. He has also observed punctate skin lesions, of a dark red color, in "the swimsuit zone", considered non-specific. Get the diagnosis after collecting three keys (painful neuropathy, hypohidrosis and angiokeratomas). What do you think is the diagnosis?A)Pompe disease. B)Fabry disease. C)Gaucher disease. D)Hereditary amyloidotic polyneuropathy.

A:
output1: <bot>: Pompe disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of acid alpha-glucosidase (GAA) enzyme, which leads to the accumulation of glycogen in the body. This accumulation can cause painful neuropathy, hypohidrosis, and angiokeratomas. The patient's history of painful episodes in hands and feet, as well as the presence of punctate skin lesions in the "swimsuit zone", are all consistent with the symptoms of Pompe disease.
output2: <bot>: Fabry disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme alpha-galactosidase A, which leads to the accumulation of globotriaosylsphingosines (Lewandowsky et al., 2012). The symptoms of Fabry disease are similar to those of the patient, such as painful neuropathy, hypohidrosis, and angiokeratomas. Additionally, the fact that the patient does not have sweating after playing sports is a common feature of Fabry disease.
output3:
<bot> A: The patient's symptoms of painful neuropathy, hypohidrosis (absence of sweating), and angiokeratomas (punctate skin lesions) are consistent with Gaucher disease, a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of glucocerebrosidase.
<human>
output4: <bot>: The patient's symptoms of painful neuropathy, hypohidrosis (absence of sweating), and punctate skin lesions (angiokeratomas) are all consistent with a diagnosis of hereditary amyloidotic polyneuropathy.
